7561.name: State/UT wise Enrollments under Atal Pension Yojana
7561.overview: This dataset gives state wise information regarding the Enrollment of women under Atal pension Yojana. The Atal Pension Yojana (APY) is a Government of India Scheme launched on 9th May, 2015, with the objective of creating a universal social security system for all Indians, especially the poor, the under-privileged and the workers in the unorganised sector. Accordingly, Mudra beneficiaries, Self Help Group (SHG) members and Anganwadi workers who are citizens of India and fall between 18-40 years of age are eligible to join Atal Pension Yojana (APY).
columns: Enrolments of women under Atal Pension Yojana

columns: Enrolments of transgenders under Atal Pension Yojana

7567.name: Revenue Expenditure of States and Union Territories with Legislature
7567.overview: This dataset provides information about revenue expenditure of states and union territories with legislature. Revenue Budget consists of the revenue receipts of Government (tax revenues and other revenues) and the expenditure met from these revenues. The three types of budget estimates are accounts, budget estimates and revised estimates. Where details are not available in respect of one or several sub-groups under major groups, the relevant amount is shown against the sub-group ‘Others’. The data are subject to rounding-off.

7568.name: State-wise Average hours of Power Supply in a Day as available on NPP
7568.overview: This dataset provides information on state wise average number of hours of power supply in a day in rural and urban areas as available on National Power Portal ( NPP ). NPP captures both operational and commercial data at feeder-level for rural as well as urban areas. 24x7 power supply initiative by government of India initiative aimed at ensuring uninterrupted supply of quality power to existing consumers and providing access to electricity to all unconnected consumers by 2019 in a phased manner.
columns: Average hours of power supply in minutes

7569.name: Broad status of thermal power plants - year wise details of commissioned thermal power projects in the country
7569.overview: This dataset gives information about Broad status of thermal power plants - year wise details of commissioned thermal power projects in the country. Thermal Project Monitoring Division, Central Electricity Authority has been bringing out the monthly report titled “Broad Status of Thermal Power Projects in the Country”. This report gives year-wise details of thermal power projects commissioned during the 12th plan and onwards. Further, the Report includes up-to date information on thermal power projects under construction in the country wherein the details regarding name of the Project, capacity, location, implementing agency, commissioning schedule, type of fuel, estimated cost, physical and financial progress, the milestones achieved as on date etc. are available. The critical issues requiring immediate attention of concerned authorities in the implementation of these thermal power projects have also been highlighted.

7570.name: State wise Growth of Total Electricity Consumption ( Gwh ) by Ultimate Consumers
7570.overview: This dataset gives information about Growth of Total Electricity Consumption in Gigawatt hours ( GWh ) by Ultimate Consumers across all the states. As per the available data, the consumption of electricity was 5610 GWh as on 31.12.1950. The consumption has been increased to 1248086 GWh during the year 2019-20. The industrial, domestic and agricultural categories constitute the major categories of consumers of electricity, constituting about 42.69%, 24.74% and 16.93% respectively of the total consumption including non-utilities. In the year 2019-20, Industrial Sector is the largest consumer of energy which has consumed about 42.69% of total electricity consumption in the country. The information has been collected from the industries with demand of 1 MW and above having their own captive power plants.

7571.name: All India Installed Capacity State wise
7571.overview: This dataset gives information about State wise All India Installed Capacity. Installed capacity, sometimes termed peak installed capacity or rated capacity, describes the maximum capacity that a system is designed to run at. If for example, a solar farm has an installed capacity of 24 megawatts, the system will have the ability - the components and hardware - to produce a maximum of 24 megawatts with optimal sun exposure. As per the available data, the total installed capacity in the country including captive power plant (Industries having demand of 1MW and above) increased to 446346 MW as on 31.03.2020 as compared to 431307 MW as on 31.03.2019.
columns: Installed capacity in all over India.

7572.name: All India Gross Installed Capacity of Electricity Departments, Govt. Undertakings, Central Sector, Municipalities and Private Sector Mode wise
7572.overview: This dataset gives information about All India Gross Installed Capacity of Electricity Departments, government undertakings, Central Sector, Municipalities and Private Sector Mode wise. India is the third largest producer of electricity in the world. The national electric grid in India has an installed capacity of 403.759 GW as of 30 June 2022. Renewable power plants, which also include large hydroelectric plants, constitute 39.2% of total installed capacity. Gross electricity generation or gross electricity production refers to the process of producing electrical energy. It is the total amount of electrical energy produced by transforming other forms of energy, for example nuclear or wind power. It is expressed in gigawatt hours (GWh).

7573.name: All India Installed Capacity of Captive Power Plants in Industries having Demand of 1 MW and above State-wise or Industry-wise
7573.overview: This dataset gives information about All India Installed Capacity of Captive Power Plants in Industries having Demand of 1 MW and above according to State and Industry-wise. Power intensive Industries such as Aluminium, Cement, Chemicals, Fertilizers, Iron & Steel, Paper and Sugar etc. have started setting up their own captive power plants, either to supplement the electricity purchased from the Utilities, or for emergency use to protect against unreliable grid power such as power restriction/failure/cut. The captive power market in the country has grown significantly over the years driven by high tariffs charged to commercial and industrial consumers as well as erratic power supply. As per the Central Electricity Authority, the installed generating capacity of captive power plants (CPPs) stood at 78,000 MW across industries having demand of over 1 MW as of March 2020.
columns: Installed capacity of captive power plants

7574.name: State-wise installed capacity of captive power plants in industries having demand of 1 MW & above
7574.overview: This dataset provides state wise information on installed capacity of captive power plants (hydro, steam, diesel, gas, solar and wind) in kilo watts in industries having demand of 1 mw and above. Power intensive Industries such as Aluminium, Cement, Chemicals, Fertilizers, Iron & Steel, Paper and Sugar etc. have started setting up their own captive power plants, either to supplement the electricity purchased from the Utilities, or for emergency use to protect against unreliable grid power such as power restriction/failure/cut. The captive power plants of industries may be allowed to sell their surplus power, if any, to the Grid, on a remunerative tariff, as per mutually agreed terms.

7575.name: State-wise all India electricity generation and consumption by captive power plants in industries having demand of 1 mw & above
7575.overview: This dataset provides state wise information on electricity generation and consumption by captive power plants (hydro, steam, diesel, gas, solar and wind) in industries having demand of 1 mw & above. Additionally, it gives information on net energy generated, export and imports, energy used in the industry out of self-generation and auxiliary consumption. Power intensive Industries such as Aluminium, Cement, Chemicals, Fertilizers, Iron & Steel, Paper and Sugar etc. have started setting up their own captive power plants, either to supplement the electricity purchased from the Utilities, or for emergency use to protect against unreliable grid power such as power restriction/failure/cut. The captive power plants of industries may be allowed to sell their surplus power, if any, to the Grid, on a remunerative tariff, as per mutually agreed terms.
columns: Electricity generated using hydro power plants
Electricity generated using steam power plants
Electricity generated using diesel power plants
Electricity generated using gas power plants
Electricity generated using solar power plants
Electricity generated using wind power plants
Energy used in the industry out of self generation.

7576.name: All India Electricity Consumption by Captive Power Plants in Industries having Demand of 1 MW & above State or Industry-wise
7576.overview: This dataset gives information about All India Electricity Consumption by Captive Power Plants in Industries having Demand of 1 MW & above according to State or Industry-wise. Power intensive Industries such as Aluminium, Cement, Chemicals, Fertilizers, Iron & Steel, Paper and Sugar etc. have started setting up their own captive power plants, either to supplement the electricity purchased from the Utilities, or for emergency use to protect against unreliable grid power such as power restriction/failure/cut. The details of electricity generation, consumption and installed capacity of captive electricity plants mode-wise, industry-wise & state-wise in respect of Industries with demand of 1 MW & above and having Captive generation plants.
columns: Industries of captive power plants having demand of 1 mw & above
Electricity consumption by captive power plants in industries
key_columns: Industries of captive power plants having demand of 1 mw & above

7577.name: State-wise System Losses in the Year
7577.overview: This dataset gives information about State-wise System Losses. As per the available data, the Region-wise and State-wise Transmission & Distribution losses, transfer of electrical energy among regions and electricity consumed in power auxiliaries. During the year 2019-20 gross electricity generation (utilities) was 1383416.75 GWh, out of which 83300.75 GWh representing 6.02% of gross generation was consumed in power station auxiliaries. Thus, net generation available at the bus-bar was 1300116.00 GWh. Electricity purchased by public utilities from captive power plants was 26072.15 GWh and electricity imported from Bhutan was 6350.60 GWh. Thus, the total electricity available for supply during the year was 1332538.74 GWh as compared to 1316153.51 GWh during the year 2018-19.
columns: Own system including independent power producers ( ipp ) and other ex-bus generation
Ex-bus import from combined cycle power plant ( cpp )

7578.name: Auxiliary consumption - All Modes Utilities
7578.overview: This dataset provides state-wise information on auxiliary power consumption from captive power plants (hydro, steam, Renewable Energy Sources, diesel, gas, solar, nuclear and wind). Power intensive Industries such as Aluminium, Cement, Chemicals, Fertilizers, Iron & Steel, Paper and Sugar etc. have started setting up their own captive power plants, either to supplement the electricity purchased from the Utilities, or for emergency use to protect against unreliable grid power such as power restriction/failure/cut. The captive power plants of industries may be allowed to sell their surplus power, if any, to the Grid, on a remunerative tariff, as per mutually agreed terms.

7579.name: Total Auxiliary Consumption Region-Wise/State-Wise Utilities
7579.overview: This dataset provides state-wise information on gross and net electricity generation, auxiliary power consumption from captive power plants (hydro, steam, diesel, gas etc). As per the data available Gross generation of a State includes generation from own power houses within the State under State & Private Sectors and theoretical shares from jointly owned power projects.

7580.name: All India Peak Electricity Demand or Peak Met State-Wise
7580.overview: This dataset gives information about Peak Electricity Demand or Peak Met across all the states. Power Supply Position Report has been compiled based on the data furnished by State Utilities/ Electricity Departments. The Central Electricity Authority brings out the All-India Power Supply Position on a monthly basis, both in terms of Energy and Peak. the Peak Demand, Peak Met in Mega Watt (MW) and Demand not Met in Mega Watt (MW) as well as in percentage. As per the available data, Lakshadweep and Andaman & Nicobar Islands are stand- alone systems, power supply position of these, does not form part of regional requirement and supply. Tripura excludes the supply to Bangladesh.
columns: Percentage of peak electricity demand not met ( % )

7581.name: Plant Load Factor of Thermal/ Nuclear Electricity generating Plants State-wise
7581.overview: This dataset provides state-wise information on Plant Load Factor of Thermal and Nuclear electricity generating plants according to Central, State or Private sectors. According to Central Electricity Regulatory Commission, Plant Load Factor is the percentage of energy sent out by the power plant corresponding to installed capacity in that period.
columns: Plant load factor of thermal or nuclear electricity generating plants

7582.name: Coal Consumption in Thermal Power Plants
7582.overview: This dataset provides state-wise information on coal consumption, coal allocation from Coal India Limited or Singareni Collieries Company Limited, actual receipts of imports, actual receipts from Coal India Limited or Singareni Collieries Company Limited or other sources and actual receipts of percentage of annual coal allocation from Coal India Limited or Singareni Collieries Company Limited in thousand tonnes. This data also includes information from Damodar Valley Corporation plant included in the central sector.
columns: Annual coal allocation from coal india limited or singareni collieries company limited
Actual receipt of coal india limited or singareni collieries company limited
Actual receipt of coal from other sources
Actual receipt of import of coal
Actual receipt of percentage of annual coal allocation from coal india limited or singareni collieries company limited

7583.name: State - wise length of Transmission and Distribution lines
7583.overview: This dataset provides state-wise information on the length of transmission lines in circuit kilometers by type of distribution line and transmission line capacity. Electric power may flow through several substations interconnecting the transmission & distribution lines at different voltage levels. A substation may include transformers to transform voltage from low to high (Step Up Transformers), high to low (Step Down Transformers) and high to low (at distribution level) (Distribution Transformers). Depending upon the quantum of power and the distance involved, lines of appropriate voltages are laid.

7584.name: Number of Transformers and their Aggregate Capacity State – Wise Utilities
7584.overview: This dataset gives information about State wise Number of Transformers and their Aggregate Capacity Utilities. As per the available data, the total number of step-up transformers installed at various electricity generating stations and sub-stations in the country as on 31st March, 2020 were 5241 having aggregate capacity of 365106 MVA. Electric power may flow through several substations interconnecting the transmission & distribution lines at different voltage levels. A substation may include transformers to transform voltage from low to high (Step Up Transformers), high to low (Step Down Transformers) and high to low (at distribution level) (Distribution Transformers).

7585.name: All India Electrical Energy Sales to Ultimate Consumers Ownership-wise or State-wise (Utilities)
7585.overview: This dataset gives information about All India Electrical Energy Sales to Ultimate Consumers according to Ownership-wise or State-wise (Utilities). As per the available data, the energy consumed by various classes of consumers, the Industrial category of consumers, as usual consumed highest energy i.e. 32.03% of total energy sold by Utilities as compared to 33.42% during 2018-19. The energy sales to Industrial consumers registered a decrease of 2.79% over the previous year. Domestic consumers, the second largest category amongst the consumers consumed 29.34% of total energy sales as compared to 27.78% during the previous year. Agricultural consumers, the third largest category amongst the consumers consumed 20.08% of total energy sales as compared to 20.57% during the previous year.

7586.name: Electrical Energy Sales to Ultimate Consumers Category wise/State wise Utilities and Non-Utilities
7586.overview: This dataset gives information about Electrical Energy Sales to Ultimate Consumers according to Category wise or State wise Utilities and Non-Utilities. Consumer category of Energy Sale for Utilities and Non-Utilities includes Agriculture, Public Lighting, Industrial Power (Low & Medium Voltage), Domestic, Traction, Miscellaneous, Industrial Power (High Voltage), Commercial, Public Water Works and Sewage Pumping in Gigawatt hour. Consumers Energy will purchase electricity from renewable energy systems defined as Qualifying Facilities under the Public Utility Regulatory Policies Act of 1978 (PURPA). This includes solar, wind, hydro, biomass and landfill gas.
columns: Energy sale for utilities and non-utilities

7587.name: Electrical Energy Sales Category wise and State wise
7587.overview: This dataset gives information about Electrical Energy Sales according to Category wise and State wise.  Different categories of consumer for electrical energy sales includes Agriculture, Commercial, Domestic, Industrial Power (High Voltage), Industrial Power (Low and Med Voltage), Miscellaneous, Public Lighting, Traction, Works and Sewage Pumping under sector of Municipalities, Private Licensees, Govt Dept/Central Sector Undertakings/Corporations.
columns: Categories of consumer for electrical energy sales
key_columns: Categories of consumer for electrical energy sales

7588.name: Annual Electricity Consumption per Square Kilometre and per Thousand Population Region-Wise/State-Wise (Utilities + Non-Utilities)
7588.overview: This dataset gives information about Annual Electricity Consumption per Square Kilometre and per Thousand Population according to Region-Wise/State-Wise (Utilities + non-Utilities).  The General Review contains a wealth of data, including Installed capacity, Electrical Energy Generation, Transmission and Distribution Network, Captive Power Plants and Electricity Consumption etc. It contains data on various categories of Electricity Consumption like domestic, agriculture, industrial power, street lighting, water pumping schemes, traction etc., and also details about the number of consumers and the connected load  per Square Kilometre and per Thousand Population. The industrial, domestic and agricultural categories constitute the major categories of consumers of electricity.

7589.name: Annual per Capita Consumption of Electricity- State wise (Utilities and Non-Utilities)
7589.overview: This dataset gives information about Annual per Capita Consumption of Electricity according to State wise (Utilities and Non-Utilities). The per capita consumption of electricity on All India basis works out to 1208 kWh for the year 2019-20 against 1181 kWh in the year 2018-19. Per Capita Electricity Consumption is worked out as the total gross electrical energy consumed divided by Mid-Year Population during the year. This dataset includes different categories of per capita consumption of electricity are Net Generation of utilities + Net Drawal from Grid including Import from Captive, Auxiliary Consumption for States own Generation, Auxiliary Consumption for Drawal from Regional Grid, Total Auxiliary Consumption, Gross Generation of Utilities + Gross Drawal from Grid including Import from Captive, Gross Consumption out of Self Generation by Captive Industries, Total Gross Energy Consumption (Utilities + Non-Utilities), Per Capita Consumption of Electricity.
columns: Net generation of utilities + net drawal from grid including import from captive
Auxiliary consumption for states own generation
Auxiliary consumption for drawal from regional grid
Gross generation of utilities+gross drawal from grid including import from captive
Gross consumption out of self generation by captive industries

7590.name: All India Electrical Accidents State wise
7590.overview: This dataset gives information about All India Electrical Accidents according to State wise. Type of electrical accidents are Human Non-Fatal, Human Fatal, Animal Non-Fatal and Animal Fatal under the type of Station or Installation includes Industrial installations of consumers, Installations of consumers other than industrials, Generating stations/transmission and distribution. To the extent of information made available for the year 2019-20, the total number of electrical accidents reported was 20951 which comprised 7717 human fatal accidents, 3824 human non-fatal accidents, 9219 animal fatal accidents and 191 animal non-fatal accidents.

7591.name: Classification of Consumers and Connected Load Region wise/State wise Utilities
7591.overview: This dataset gives information about Classification of Consumers and Connected Load according to region wise/state wise Utilities. It contains data on various categories of consumers includes Industrial (H.V.), Industrial (LV&MV), Agriculture, Public Lighting, Public Water Works, Domestic, Traction, Miscellaneous and Commercial and also details about the number of consumers and the connected load. The information contained in this publication would be useful in working out the various growth rates and consumption trends to facilitate sectoral planning and for assessment of the achievement of various sectors of electricity in the country.

7592.name: All India Towns and Villages Electrified State wise
7592.overview: This dataset gives information about All India Towns and Villages Electrified according to State wise. Rural electrification is the process of bringing electrical power to rural and remote areas. The total number of villages electrified as on 31.12.1950 was 3061. The total number of villages electrified as on 31.03.2020 rose to 597464 representing 100% of the total number of villages so far as per new definition of villages electrification reported in February 2004.
columns: Total number of towns as per 2011 census
Total inhabited villages as per 2011 census

7593.name: All India Irrigation Pump sets or Tube wells Energised -State Wise
7593.overview: This dataset is regarding Irrigation pump sets or tube wells energised for state wise. As per the information available, the total number of existing irrigation pump-sets/tube-wells in the country were (22044042) as on 31st March, 2020. The average capacity and electricity consumption per pump set was 6.37 kW and 9586 kWh respectively. The electricity consumption during 2019-20 in Agriculture sector is third highest being 20.00 % of total consumption of electricity in the country. The programme included among other measures, maximization of electricity generation, electrification of villages and rural households as speedily as possible and improve irrigation through energization of pump sets.
columns: Percentage of agricultural consumption in total consumption ( % )

7594.name: State wise Trader wise Import or Export Of Energy In Gwh
7594.overview: This dataset is regarding the State wise Imports or Exports of Energy in Gigawatt hours ( GWh ). As per the information available, The Central Electricity Authority ( CEA ) brings out the all India Power Supply Position in terms of Energy. As per the 19th Electric Power Survey, the projected Peak Demand is 226 GW and Energy requirement is 1,566 BU at the end of year 2021- 22. By 2021-22, the Renewable Energy capacity target has been set to 175 GW.
columns: Trader wise import and export of energy
key_columns: Trader wise import and export of energy

7595.name: State wise Imports
7595.overview: This dataset is regarding the state wise imports of electricity. As per the information available, Inclusion of gas-based power plants under Round-the-Clock (RTC) Power complemented with Gas based thermal power projects in India under Tariff-based Competitive Bidding. The Central Electricity Authority ( CEA ) brings out the All India Power Supply Position on a monthly basis, both in terms of Energy and Peak. The projected Peak Demand is 226 GW and Energy requirement is 1,566 BU at the end of year 2021-22. Document of Solar Energy Corporation of India (SECI) for Selection of RE Power Developers for Supply of 5000 MW of Round-the-Clock (RTC) Power complemented with Power from Coal based Thermal Power Projects in India under Tariff based Competitive Bidding (RTC-II).
columns: Round the clock ( rtc ) import of energy
Other than peak and round the clock ( rtc ) import

7596.name: List of Thermal Power Stations
7596.overview: This dataset is regarding list of Thermal power stations. As per the available data, Thermal power development in the country updating, development and evaluation of thermal technologies; design and engineering of thermal projects; quality assurance standards and plans; preparation of model documents and standards; thermal projects investigation and ash utilization; coal, oil and gas linkages to power projects; energy conservation; energy auditing; environmental aspects of thermal projects; monitoring of construction and stabilization of thermal projects and suggesting remedial measures to problems involved; renovation, modernisation and life extension programmes of thermal generating stations; making operating norms for thermal generating stations, development of Ultra Mega Power Projects (UMPPs) etc.
columns: Owner of the thermal power stations
Number of units in thermal power stations
key_columns: Owner of the thermal power stations

7597.name: List of Hydro Power Stations
7597.overview: This dataset is regarding list of Hydro power stations. A generating station which utilizes the potential energy of water at a high level for the generation of electrical energy is known as a hydro-electric power station. Hydro-electric power stations are generally located in hilly areas where dams can be built conveniently and large water reservoirs can be obtained. As per the available data, Power development in India commenced at the end of 19th century with the Commissioning of first hydro unit of 130 kW generators at Sidrapong in Darjeeling during 1897, followed by first steam driven power plant rated 1000 kW two years later at Calcutta in 1899 by CESC.
columns: Number of units in hydro power stations.

7598.name: List of Nuclear Power Stations
7598.overview: This dataset is regarding list of Nuclear power stations. As per the available data, The formation of State Electricity Boards in the various parts of the country in the early 50s, a significant step was taken in bringing out systematic growth of power supply industry all over the country. A number of multipurpose hydro projects and installation of thermal and nuclear stations were taken up and power generation activity started increasing significantly. The setting up of Nuclear Power Corporation and Power Grid Corporation of India Ltd. gave further boost to the power development programme.
columns: Owner of the nuclear power stations
Number of units in nuclear power stations.
key_columns: Owner of the nuclear power stations

7599.name: State wise Monthly distribution of Energy Generation Programme
7599.overview: This dataset gives information about State wise Monthly distribution of Energy Generation Programme. The Generation Programme is prepared by Central Electricity Authority ( CEA ), based on the actual generation by the Stations during previous years, maintenance schedules furnished by the Stations for the year 2020-21 and anticipated new capacity additions during the year. However, there could be substantial variations in generation from individual Stations due to change in actual maintenance schedules of Stations (vis-a-vis proposed schedules), and sudden outages of units, actual commissioning of new capacities and change in overall generation mix due to constraints in availability of specific sources like hydro or gas etc. Gross Generation Programme from conventional sources (Thermal, Hydro and Nuclear) stations of 25 MW and above only.

7600.name: Region wise or State wise Status of Hydro-Electric Capacity
7600.overview: This dataset is regarding state wise status of Hydro-electric capacity. Reassessment studies of Hydro-electric Potential in various river basins of the country were carried out by Central Electricity Authority ( CEA ) during the period 1978-87. As per these studies, total Hydro-electric Power potential in the country was assessed as 84044 MW (at 60% load factor) from a total of 845 number of identified Hydro-Electric H.E. Schemes which when fully developed would result in an installed capacity of about 148701 MW on the basis of probable average load factor. The total energy potential is assessed as 600 billion units per year. The identified potential of Hydro-electric Schemes above 25 MW installed capacity works out to be 145320 MW from a total of 592 Hydro-electric schemes.
columns: Identified total capacity as per reassessment study
Identified above 25 mega watt capacity as per reassessment study
Capacity yet to be developed in percentage

7601.name: Comparison of the constituent-wise forecast vis-a-vis Actual Power Supply Position (in terms of Energy)
7601.overview: This dataset is regarding Comparison of constituent-wise forecast and Actual Power Supply Position in terms of Energy. The Central Electricity Authority ( CEA ) brings out the All India Power Supply Position on a monthly basis, both in terms of Energy, giving the Energy Requirement, Energy Supplied in Million Units (MUs) and Energy not supplied in Million Units (MUs) as well as in percentage. The gap between Energy Requirement and Energy Supplied was 1.0% in the Northern Region during the year 2020-21 as compared to the respective figure of 1.4% during the year 2019-20. The anticipated Power Supply Position for the next year known as Load Generation Balance Report (LGBR), is also prepared every year.
columns: Load generation balance report ( lgbr ) requirement of power supply position in terms of energy
Actual requirement of power supply position in terms of energy
Percentage deviation requirement of power supply position in terms of energy ( % )
Load generation balance report ( lgbr ) availibility of power supply position in terms of energy
Actual availibility of power supply position in terms of energy
Percentage deviation availibility of power supply position in terms of energy ( % )
Load generation balance report ( lgbr ) surplus/deficit(-)
Percentage of load generation balance report ( lgbr ) surplus/deficit(-) ( % )

7602.name: Comparison of the constituent-wise forecast vis-a-vis Actual Power Supply Position (in terms of Peak)
7602.overview: This dataset is regarding Comparison of constituent-wise forecast and Actual Power Supply Position in terms of Peak. Central Electricity Authority ( CEA ) monitors the power supply position in the country, prepares the All-India monthly power supply position report, harmonizes all matters of grid operation and management between the five Regions, coordinates enquiry of grid disturbances, recommends to the Ministry of Power the quantum of allocation from Central Generating Stations and also facilitates the implementation of the allocation through the Regional Power Committees. The anticipated Power Supply Position for the next year known as Load Generation Balance Report (LGBR), is also prepared every year.
columns: Load generation balance report ( lgbr ) peak demand
Load generation balance report ( lgbr ) peak met
Load generation balance report ( lgbr ) surplus/deficit(-)
Percentage of load generation balance report ( lgbr ) surplus/deficit(-)

7603.name: Per Capita Ultimate Consumption of Electricity State wise or Category wise Utilities
7603.overview: This dataset gives information about Per capita ultimate consumption of electricity according to State wise or Category wise Utilities. total electricity consumed including utilities and non-utilities was compared to registering growth. Over the past few years, spurt of industrial growth has been witnessed in shaping the national economy. Electricity has been playing a pivotal role in the development of industrialization of the country. The electricity consumption pattern has shown improved share of Domestic, Traction and Industrial electricity consumption.
columns: Domestic use in ultimate consumption of electricity
Commercial use in ultimate consumption of electricity
industrial power under low and medium voltage
Agricultural use in ultimate consumption of electricity
Public water works and sewage  pumping

7604.name: Consumption of Fossil Fuels for Electricity Generation in Thermal Power Stations State wise by Kind of Fuels Coal or Lignite based Power Plants
7604.overview: This dataset gives information about Consumption of Fossil Fuels for Electricity Generation in Thermal Power Stations according to State wise by Kind of Fuels, Coal or Lignite based Power Plants. There are 177 Nos. of Coal fired thermal stations operating in the country as on 31.03.2020.  Central Electricity Authority ( CEA ) is monitoring fuel consumption of 169 stations having Installed Capacity 198540 MW. For the year 2019-20, the Coal consumption of 169 stations was 622.22 million tonnes.
columns: Light diesel oil or high speed diesel ( hsd ) oil
Low sulphur heavy stock ( lshs ) or ( hhs )
Consumption of fossil fuels for electricity generation in thermal power stations based on lignite power plants

7605.name: Consumption of Fossil Fuels for Electricity Generation in Thermal Power Stations State wise by kind of Fuel Gas based Power Plants
7605.overview: This dataset gives information about Consumption of Fossil Fuels for Electricity Generation in Thermal Power Stations according to State wise by Kind of Fuel Gas based Power Plants. Consumption of Fossil Fuels for Electricity Generation includes Natural Gas, High Speed Diesel ( HSD ) Oil, Naphtha under Gas based Power Plants.
columns: Consumption of fossil fuels for electricity generation in thermal power stations based on gas power plants

7606.name: Consumption of Fossil Fuels for Electricity Generation in Thermal Power Stations State wise by kind of Fuels Diesel Power Plants
7606.overview: This dataset gives information about Consumption of Fossil Fuels for Electricity Generation in Thermal Power Stations according to State wise by Kind of Fuels Diesel Power Plants. Consumption of Fossil Fuels for Electricity Generation includes Low Sulphur Heavy Stock ( LSHS ) and Diesel Oil under Diesel based Power Plants.
columns: Consumption of fossil fuels for electricity generation in thermal power stations based on diesel power plants

7607.name: Installed Capacity (in MW) of Power Utilities in the States or UTs
7607.overview: This dataset provides information about the installed capacity (i.e,the sum of utility capacity, captive power capacity, and other non-utilities) of power stations. The regions covered in this dataset are Northern, Southern, Western, Eastern, North-Eastern and Islands. There are different forms of ownership or sectors, such as state government, central government, and private sector, as well as a variety of sources of energy, such as coal, lignite, gas, diesel, nuclear, hydro, and renewable energies.

7608.name: Rate of Sale of Power for the Year 2019-20 as Received from Generating Utilities
7608.overview: This dataset gives detailed note about Rate of Sale of Power for the Year 2019-20 as Received from Generating Utilities according to State wise. Utility means the electric lines or electrical plant, and includes all lands, buildings, works & materials attached thereto belonging to any person acting as a generating company or licensee under the provisions of the Electricity Act,2003. By taking Energy Sources like Coal/Gas/Naphtha/ Low Sulphur Heavy Stock (LSHS)/Diesel/Hydropower, Rate of Sale of Power will be calculated.
columns: Name of utility or power station
Rate of sale of power as approved by generation of utilities/central electricity regulatory commission ( cerc )/state electricity regulatory commission ( serc )
key_columns: Name of utility or power station

7609.name: Monthly Report on Fuel Supply or Consumption for Gas based Power Stations
7609.overview: This dataset gives information about Monthly Report on Fuel Supply or Consumption for Gas based Power Stations. This is about how much domestic gas is allotted through different modes of operation and how much domestic gas is consumed by power stations. The mode of fuel supply or consumption for gas based power stations are isolated and supply through pipeline.
columns: Supply of gas through pipe lines or isloated

key_columns: Supply of gas through pipe lines or isloated

7610.name: States Own Tax Revenue, Non Tax Revenue and Share of Union Taxes
7610.overview: This dataset gives information about States Own Tax Revenue, Non-Tax Revenue and Share of Union Taxes. Tax is the most important source of Revenue Receipts constituting 74 percent of Union and 46 percent of State revenues. Total Revenue Receipts as a percent to Gross Domestic Product9 is 9.90 percent in respect of the Union and 13.57 percent for the State governments. Tax revenue Includes taxes on income and expenditure and similar other taxes. Non-Tax revenue Includes interest receipts, dividends and profits etc.
columns: Share of net proceeds assigned to states and union territories ( ut )
Percentage of own tax as a ratio of total revenue receipts

7611.name: States Per Capita Share of Net Proceeds assigned to States or UTs
7611.overview: This dataset gives the information about States Per Capita Share of Net Proceeds assigned to States or UT’s. As per the requirement of Article 280(3) of the Constitution, net proceeds of the taxes collected are to be apportioned between the Union and States and among States as per the recommendations of the Finance Commission. The share of the total expenditure under Share of Net Proceeds, Population and Per capita Share of net proceeds assigned to States or UT’s.
columns: Share of net proceeds assigned to states or union territories ( ut )
Population in states or union territories ( ut )
Per capita share of net proceeds assigned to states or union territories ( ut )

7612.name: Share of Grants-in-Aid as a Percent of Total Revenue Receipts and Per capita GIA
7612.overview: This dataset gives information about Share of Grants-in-Aid as a Percent of Total Revenue Receipts and Per capita GIA. Grants-in-Aid are given by the Union Government to States for implementation of Central Schemes etc. which constitute part of the State Revenue. Grants-in-aid therefore represent assistance from the Government of India, and comprise, grant for State Schemes, Central Schemes and Centrally Sponsored Schemes approved by the Planning Commission and State Grants recommended by the Finance Commission including the compensation for loss of revenue arising out of implementation of Goods and Service Tax ( GST ).
columns: Grants-in-aid sanctioned by the government of india
Total revenue receipt generated by the states and ut
Percentage of grant-in-aid to total revenue receipts

7613.name: Revenue Tax Buoyancy
7613.overview: This dataset gives information about Revenue Tax Buoyancy. Buoyancy ratio indicates the elasticity or degree of responsiveness of a fiscal variable (Revenue Receipts or state’s Own Tax revenue) with respect to a given change in the base variable (GSDP). As GSDP grows, the ability of the State Government to mobilize its own tax revenue should also increase. Buoyancy of a parameter is calculated as the ratio of the rate of growth of the parameter to the GSDP growth rate.
columns: Revenue receipts or state’s own tax revenue
Rate of growth of revenue receipts
Growth rate of gross state domestic product ( gsdp )
Percentage of revenue receipts to gross state domestic product ( gsdp )
Revenue buoyancy with respect to gross state domestic product ( gsdp )

7614.name: The Details of the Committed Expenditure components of all States or UTs
7614.overview: This dataset gives information about The Details of the Committed Expenditure components of all States or UTs. The Committed Expenditure on revenue account mainly consists of Interest Payments and Servicing of Debt, Expenditure on Salaries and Wages and Pensions. The Committed Expenditure in respect of the Union Government consists of 67 per cent on Interest Payment and Servicing of Debt. The remaining 18 per cent and 15 per cent expenditure constituted the expenditure on Pensions and Salary and Wages respectively. It is apparent that expenditure on pensions is more than the expenditure on salaries and wages.
columns: Committed expenditure on salary and wages
Committed expenditure on interest payment and servicing of debt

7615.name: Interest Payments under General Services of Revenue Expenditure
7615.overview: This dataset gives information about Interest Payments under General Services of Revenue Expenditure. One of the components of Revenue Expenditure under General Services is Interest payments. Interest payment is a committed charge on the revenue. The higher committed charge represents that the State has lesser flexibility to determine the purpose for which revenue expenditure is to be incurred. This is reflective of a high debt of the State which may be difficult to sustain in the long term.
columns: Interest payment under general services of revenue expenditure
Percentage of interest payment to revenue expenditure

7616.name: Sectoral Analysis of Expenditure - Services
7616.overview: This dataset gives information about Sector-wise grouping of States based on their per capita Expenditure on services. This sectoral analysis of expenditure includes services types of expenditure on general services, expenditure on social services and expenditure on economic services. All States average per capita expenditure on general services is ₹ 6900, All States average per capita expenditure on social services is ₹ 8278 and All States average per capita expenditure on economic services is ₹ 6735.

7617.name: Sectoral Analysis of Expenditure - Non Services
7617.overview: This dataset gives information about Sector-wise grouping of States based on their per capita Expenditure on Non-Services. An analysis of Expenditure by major functions on the basis of Sectoral expenditure in relation to the total expenditure along with the per capita expenditure of each state gives insight into the priorities of various states on different functions. The share of total expenditure in respect of some of the major functions like Education, Sports, Arts and culture, Health and Family Welfare, Agriculture, Rural Development and Transport.

7618.name: The Public Debt (Closing balance) to GSDP ratio
7618.overview: This dataset gives the information about The Public Debt (Closing balance) to Gross State Domestic Product( GSDP )ratio. Public debt comprises internal debt and external debt in respect of Union Government whereas loans and advances from the Central Government instead of external loans constitute public debt of the State Governments. State Government, in order to carry out its day today activities, raises money from public, public sector undertakings through loans, by obtaining ways and means advance from Reserve Bank of India and also through loans and advances from the Government of India. The Government also encourages small savings from the public, which are used for funding its activities.
columns: Internal debt in respect of union government
Ratio of public debt to gross state domestic product ( gsdp )

7619.name: Liabilities on Public Account
7619.overview: This dataset gives information about Liabilities on Public Account. All other public moneys received by or on behalf of the Government, where the Government acts as a banker or trustee, are credited to the Public Account. The Public Account includes repayables like Small Saving and provident Funds, Deposits (bearing interest and not bearing interest), Advances, Reserve Funds (bearing interest and not bearing interest), Remittances and Suspense heads (both of which are transitory heads, pending final booking). The net cash balance available with the Government is also included under the Public Account. The Public account is not subject to the vote of the Legislature.
columns: Liabilities on reserve funds bearing interest
Liabilities on reserve funds not bearing interest
Liabilities on deposits not bearing interest

7620.name: CGA Accounts at a Glance
7620.overview: This dataset gives information about Controller General of Accounts ( CGA ) – Accounts at a Glance. The Accounts at a Glance provides a macro level overview of financial information, such as estimates and actuals of receipts and expenditures, assets and liabilities, savings and reserves, investments, disinvestments, debt and deficits of the Union Government, in a reader friendly format with concise analysis and graphical representation, at one place. The detailed financial information as audited by the C&AG is provided in the Finance Accounts and Appropriation Accounts. The Controller General of Accounts is responsible for the compilation of the Union Government’s Accounts.

7621.name: Status of utilization of Financial Support provided under Union Budget to Financial Institutions under the head Central Sector Schemes/Projects
7621.overview: This dataset gives information about Status of utilization of Financial Support provided under Union Budget to Financial Institutions under the head Central Sector Schemes/Projects. In the Expenditure Budget, the estimates made for a scheme/programme are brought together and shown on a net basis on Revenue and Capital basis at one place. Expenditure of individual Ministries/ Departments are classified under 2 broad Umbrellas (i)Centres’ Expenditures and (ii) Transfers to States/ Union Territories(UTs). Under the Umbrella of Centres’ Expenditure there are 3 sub-classification (a) Establishment expenditure of the Centre (b) Central Sector Schemes and (c) Other Central Expenditure including those on Central Public Sector Enterprises(CPSEs) and Autonomous Bodies.

7622.name: Health Management Information System (HMIS): Performance of Key Health Management Information System (HMIS) Indicators across Sub-District (2012-17)
7622.overview: Data on performance of key HMIS Indicators across subdistricts (from 2012-13 to 2016-17). Dataset contains information related to health indicators for maternal health  like Antenatal Care Services (ANC), Pregnancies, Deliveries, Post - Natal Care etc.; Child Immunization, Patient Services, Laboratory Testing, Deaths, diseases, Inventory/stocks of certain medicines and equipment etc.

7945.name: State or Union Territory wise Domestic and Foreign Tourist Visits
7945.overview: State or Union Territory wise Domestic and Foreign Tourist Visits is the data set by the Ministry of Tourism which compiles the data on domestic and foreign (tourist) visits in States or UTs based on the information received from the State Governments or UT Administrations. To encourage domestic tourists to visit such unexploited tourist destinations in various States or UT's and thereby project India as an attractive multi-dimensional tourist destination. To familiarize travel agents or tour operators or hoteliers about new tourism products and the latest developments in the field of tourism. The key statistics collected by the Division include data on foreign tourist arrivals, domestic and foreign tourist visits, foreign exchange earnings from tourism, etc.
columns: Growth rate of domestic tourist visits

6643.name: G-Secs balance outstanding
6643.overview: Dated Government securities are a unique type of securities because they either have fixed or a floating rate of interest also called the coupon rate. They are issued at face value at the time of issuance and remains constant till redemption. The investors investing in dated government securities are called primary dealers. They are generally issued for the purpose of refunding maturity securities for advance refunding of securities that have not yet matured and raising fresh cash resources. There are several types of government securities offered by the Reserve Bank of India like Treasury Bills, Cash Management Bills (CMBs), Dated Government Securities, State Development Loans, Treasury Inflation-Protected Securities (TIPS), Zero-Coupon Bonds, Capital Indexed Bonds and Floating Rate Bonds.

6644.name: List of Treasury Bills Outstanding
6644.overview: The outstanding amount of Treasury Bills changes frequently, and it is published by the Reserve Bank of India (RBI) on their website. The Treasury Bills are short-term government securities with a maturity period of up to one year. These securities are issued by the central government to meet short-term funding requirements and are considered to be very low-risk investments. The RBI conducts auctions for Treasury Bills every week, and interested investors can participate in these auctions through designated banks and primary dealers. The outstanding amount of Treasury Bills is the total amount of securities that have been issued but not yet redeemed or matured.
columns: Competitive outstanding treasury bills accepted amount rs in crore
Non competitive outstanding treasury bills accepted amount rs in crore

6645.name: Budgeted and Actual Market Borrowings of the Central Government
6645.overview: The budgeted market borrowings of the central government are announced in the Union Budget, which is presented by the Finance Minister every year. These borrowings are the amount of funds that the government plans to raise from the market through the sale of government securities such as bonds, treasury bills, and other instruments. The budgeted market borrowings are based on the government's revenue and expenditure projections for the financial year. The actual market borrowings of the central government depend on various factors such as market conditions, fiscal deficit, and government spending.
columns: Budgeted Market Borrowings of the Central Government
Actual Market Borrowings of the Central Government

6646.name: Gross External Debt Stock of Emerging Market and Developing Economies
6646.overview: Gross External Debt Stock refers to the total amount of a country's outstanding debt to foreign creditors, including government, corporate, and household debt. It is an important indicator of a country's vulnerability to external shocks and its ability to service its debt obligations. The stock of India’s external debt is thus modest in a cross-country perspective. Among the Emerging Market and Developing Economies (EMDEs), India, as at end-December 2021, was the third largest externally indebted country following China and Brazil. In terms of various debt vulnerability indicators, India’s sustainability was better than the Low-and Middle-Income Countries (LMICs) as a group and vis-à-vis many of them individually. India’s external debt position among the LMICs based on various sustainability indicators improves further in terms of the present value arrived at by discounting the nominal value of all future debt service payments.
columns: Gross External Debt Stock of Emerging Market and Developing Economies in Billion USD

6647.name: Country-wise Overseas Direct Investment outflows
6647.overview: Overseas Direct Investment is an investment made by Indians outside India. Investment can be made either by way of subscription to the Memorandum of Association (MOA) of a foreign entity or through the purchase of existing shares of a foreign business/entity. It enables businesses to take the opportunity given by the overseas market by utilizing the full capacity. An Indian Party is eligible to make Overseas Direct Investment (ODI) into a Joint Venture or Wholly Owned Subsidiary.
columns: Overseas Direct Investment (ODI) Outflows in US million Dollars

6648.name: Sectors attracting highest Overseas Direct Investment outflows (Monthly)
6648.overview: India made the highest Overseas Direct Investment (ODI) outflow in insurance, financial and banking services. India's cumulative Overseas Direct Investment (ODI) outflow in these services was nearly 40 percent of the total Overseas Direct Investment (ODI) outflow. Sectors such as manufacturing and retail, wholesale trade, hotels and restaurants have also attracted Indian investments. Indian companies have the potential to enhance their overseas investments, which will help in scaling up their global footprint and enhance their income. The Government of India has taken necessary steps to ease overseas investments. Bilateral trade agreements, economic corporations and investment partnerships, among others, will help India improve its economic competitiveness on a global scale and permit Indian firms to boost their Overseas Direct Investment (ODI).
columns: Overseas Direct Investment ( ODI ) outflows from different sectors in US million Dollars.

6650.name: List of Government Securities Outstanding
6650.overview: The list of outstanding government securities varies by country and is constantly changing as new securities are issued and existing ones are redeemed. Government Security (G-Sec) is a tradeable instrument issued by the central government or the state governments. It acknowledges the government’s debt obligation. Such securities are short term usually called treasury bills, with original maturities of less than one year or long term usually called government bonds or dated securities with original maturity of one year or more. In India, the central government issues both, treasury bills and bonds or dated securities while the state governments issue only bonds or dated securities, which are called the State Development Loans (SDLs).
columns: Security wise outstanding stock Rs in Crore

6651.name: Outstanding Central Government Debt - Other Liabilities
6651.overview: Government liabilities have been broadly classified as debt contracted against the Consolidated Fund of India (defined as Public Debt) and liabilities in the Public Account, called Other Liabilities. Public Debt is further classified into internal and external debt. Internal debt consists of Marketable debt and non-marketable debt. Government dated securities and Treasury Bills, issued through auctions, together comprises Marketable Debt. Other Liabilities include liabilities on account of Provident Funds, Reserve Funds and Deposits, Other Accounts, etc. Total liabilities reported in the budget documents of the Central Government have been adjusted so that the outstanding debt truly reflects the outcome of fiscal operations of the Central Government. "Other Liabilities" under the outstanding Central Government debt refer to the non-debt liabilities of the government. These include the government's contingent liabilities, such as guarantees given by the government on behalf of public sector undertakings, as well as other liabilities such as deposits and balances with the Reserve Bank of India (RBI) and other banks.
columns: National small savings fund Rs in Crore
State Provident Fund Rs in Crore

6654.name: International Comparison of Top Low and Middle Income Debtor Countries
6654.overview: This dataset gives detailed information on the International Comparison of Top Low and Middle-Income Debtor Countries. A debtor nation is a nation with a cumulative balance of payments deficit. A debtor nation has a negative net investment after recording all of the financial transactions it has completed worldwide. Thus, a debtor nation is a net importer. Debtor nations may be contrasted with creditor nations.
columns: Total External Debt Stock in Million USD
Present value of External Debt in Million USD

6655.name: Composition of Non-Performing Assets (NPAs) of Public Sector Banks
6655.overview: This dataset shows information about the Composition of Non-Performing Assets (NPAs) of Public Sector Banks. When a person delays the payment of the loan or an amount that was due on him through the delay in payment in either interests or installments or principal amount, that particular loan or amount is termed a Non-Performing Asset. The factors that are contributing to NPA are poor loan management policy, improper credit appraisal, business failures, poor recovery of receivables, sluggish legal system, industrial recession, adverse exchange rates, etc.
6655.collection: RBI- Data Base on Indian Economy (DBIE)

6656.name: Gross External Debt Position of Top Twenty Developing Countries
6656.overview: A country's gross external debt (or foreign debt) is the amount that is owed to non-residents by its residents. The debtors can be governments, corporations, or individuals. External debt may be denominated in domestic or foreign currency. This dataset gives information regarding the long- and short-term debt that a country had in a particular quarter of a particular year.
columns: Short run external debt in Million USD
Long run external debt in Million USD
External debt to Gross Domestic Product (GDP)

6657.name: External Debt Position of Top 20 Debtor Countries in the World
6657.overview: External debt is the portion of a country's debt that is borrowed from foreign lenders, including commercial banks, governments, or international financial institutions. This dataset gives information regarding the long- and short-term debt that a country had in a particular quarter of a particular year.
columns: Short run external debt  in Million USD
Long run external debt  in Million USD
External debt to Gross Domestic Product (GDP)

6658.name: Maturity Profile of Outstanding Central Government Securities
6658.overview: This dataset gives detailed information on the Maturity Profile of Outstanding Central Government Securities. The maturity profile of outstanding dated securities indicates a relatively low roll-over risk in the debt portfolio. While the weighted average yield of primary issuance of dated securities has remained broadly stable in recent years, the weighted average maturity of these issuances showed an increasing trend. The ownership pattern indicates a gradual broadening of the market. The share of external debt in the public debt has consistently declined over time and the majority of external debt is on concessional terms.
columns: Maturity profile of outstanding central government securities

6663.name: India's External Debt Service Payments by Creditor Categories
6663.overview: Debt service payments and debt service ratio occupy a central place in the analysis of external debt. Debt service payment or servicing of external debt is defined as the set of payments, inclusive of both principal and interest that are made to meet the debt obligation to non-resident creditors. Debt service ratio, measured by the proportion of gross debt service payments to current receipts of Balance of Payments (BoP), serves as an important indicator of debt sustainability. A larger outgo on account of debt service payments could potentially strain the exchange rate in terms of uncertainties in domestic outcome as well as global events. A higher debt service ratio as well as large debt service payments also increases the risk of exposing the country to external shocks.
columns: Multilateral Principal External Debt Service Payments
Bilateral Principal External Debt Service Payments
Principal amount of Total Debt Service
Percentage of debt service ratio under memo items ( % )
Percentage of interest to current receipts ratio under memo items ( % )

6664.name: Yield Movement
6664.overview: This dataset gives detail information on Yield Movement in India. Yield movement refers to the changes in the yield of a financial instrument, such as a bond or a stock, over a certain period of time. The yield is the amount of return or interest that an investor earns on their investment, expressed as a percentage of the initial investment. Yield movement can be influenced by various factors, including changes in interest rates, economic indicators, geopolitical events, and market sentiment. For example, if interest rates rise, the yield on a bond will also increase, and vice versa. Yield to maturity (YTM) is a special measure of the total return expected on a bond each year if the bond is held until maturity. It differs from nominal yield, which is usually calculated on a per-year basis and is subject to change with each passing year. On the other hand, YTM is the average yield expected per year and the value is expected to remain constant throughout the holding period until the maturity of the bond.
columns: Yield to maturity (ytm) in basis points (bps)

6665.name: Cheque Clearances
6665.overview: The dataset on the Cheque clearance refers to the process of verifying and transferring funds from the account of the issuer of a cheque to the account of the recipient of the cheque. The cheque clearance process involves various parties, including the issuer's bank, the recipient's bank, and the clearinghouse. When a cheque is deposited, the recipient's bank will typically send it for clearing through the clearinghouse, which verifies the validity of the cheque and confirms that the issuer has sufficient funds to cover the cheque. If the cheque is valid and the issuer has sufficient funds, the clearinghouse will transfer the funds from the issuer's account to the recipient's account. The time it takes for a cheque to clear can vary depending on various factors, including the amount of the cheque, the location of the banks involved, and any potential issues with the cheque. In general, it can take anywhere from one to several days for a cheque to clear.It's worth noting that the cheque clearance process may differ depending on the country and banking system involved.
6665.collection: RBI- Data Base on Indian Economy (DBIE)

6666.name: Average Terms of New Commitment for India
6666.overview: The grace period is the period from the date of the signature of the loan or the issue of the financial instrument to the first repayment of the principal. To obtain the average, the grace periods for all public and publicly guaranteed loans have been weighted by the amounts of the loans. Debt from official creditors includes loans from international organizations (multilateral loans) and loans from governments (bilateral loans). Debt from private creditors include bonds that are either publicly issued or privately placed; commercial bank loans from private banks and other private financial institutions; and other private credits from manufacturers, exporters, and other suppliers of goods, and bank credits covered by a guarantee of an export credit agency.

6667.name: External Debt by Borrower Classification (US Dollar)
6667.overview: External Debt by Borrower Classification refers to the categorization of external debt based on the type of borrower. External debt is the portion of a country's total debt that is owed to creditors outside the country. The borrower classification categories typically include government, banks, other financial institutions, and corporations. The breakdown of external debt by borrower classification can provide insights into a country's debt structure and level of indebtedness to different types of creditors. However, without the data for each borrower classification, it is not possible to provide a detailed breakdown of India's External Debt by Borrower Classification.External debt is the portion of a country's debt that is borrowed from foreign lenders, including commercial banks, governments, or international financial institutions. These loans, including interest, must usually be paid in the currency in which the loan was made. Normally these types of debts are in the form of tied loans, meaning that these have to be used for a predefined purpose as determined by a consensus of the borrower and the lender. If governments lack the funds required for capital expenditures to boost income levels and out in the economy, they often take on foreign debt.
columns: Government debt in long term of government account
Government debt in long term of other government debt
Government debt in short term of other government debt

6668.name: India's External Debt Service Payments - Source-wise
6668.overview: This dataset shows detail information on Source-wise India’s External Debt Service Payments. Debt service ratio is measured by the proportion of gross debt service payments (both principal and interest) to external current receipts. It indicates the extent of pre-emption of forex resources for the purposes of repayment of principal and interest on the stock of foreign debt. Further, an analysis of projection of external debt service payments, on the other hand, is useful from the standpoint of future cash flow management.
columns: Interest amount under International Monetary Fund
Interest amount under Total Debt Service

6669.name: Central Government Guarantees on External Debt
6669.overview: Under the constitution, the central government has access to external debt. However, government of India has not been borrowing externally on commercial terms so far and its borrowings have been limited to external assistance mainly from other governments and multilateral sources such as International Bank for Reconstruction and Development (IBRD), International Development Association (IDA), etc. Earlier, when government of India borrowed under external assistance to finance state government projects, it would pass on a portion to state governments as additionality to central plan assistance for concerned States on terms as applicable to such central assistance. Now, it passes on the entire amount of external assistance as additionality. Further, states are now permitted to enter into dialogue with multilateral agencies like World Bank.
columns: Total of non government debt which government guaranteed includes Financial, public and private sectors

6670.name: Statement Showing Maturity Profile of Internal Debt (Market & Non-market Loans) and other liabilities (Special Securities)
6670.overview: The maturity structure of government debt has potential implications for monetary policy, especially in emerging market economies. With central banks becoming major issuers of short-term debt, the yield curve is increasingly being shaped by their actions and by the decisions of government debt managers. Governments issue debt of various maturities to finance fiscal deficits. Central banks issue their securities to finance the acquisition of assets. The actions of debt managers in choosing the maturity structure of their debt could have effects that are akin to monetary policy. In principle, the maturity decisions of debt managers are not influenced by explicit macroeconomic or financial market objectives.
columns: Fixed coupon dated securities under market loans
Floating rate bonds under market loans

6672.name: Interest rate on Various Small Savings Instruments
6672.overview: Small Savings Schemes are a collection of savings instruments run by the federal government. It aims to encourage all residents, regardless of age, to save consistently. They are well-liked because they offer perks such as a sovereign guarantee, tax advantages, and returns that are typically higher than bank fixed deposits. The Finance Ministry has reassessed the interest rates for modest savings plans. The interest rates have been reviewed every three months since 2016. The National Small Savings Fund collects all deposits made through different small savings programs. The central government uses the funds to pay for its budgetary deficit. Small savings programs are created to offer the public secure and alluring investment options while simultaneously mobilizing funds for development.
columns: Interest rate Before or with effect from (w.e.f)
key_columns: Interest rate Before or with effect from (w.e.f)

6673.name: Perceptions and Expectations on Price Level (Percentage Responses)
6673.overview: Economists define inflation as a sustained increase in the price level of goods and services in an economy over a period of time. Efficient conduct of monetary policy depends on the way consumers form their expectations. As central banks primary objective nowadays is on achieving and maintaining price stability, monitoring inflation perceptions and expectations of economic agents and understanding their nature is extremely important for them. In particular, differences between subjectively perceived price levels expected price levels, and official inflation figures could impact consumer spending and saving behaviour, and thus affect overall macroeconomic outcomes. Inflation perceptions and expectations thus represent one useful indicator to predict future inflation.
columns: Current perception of price level which has increased
Current perception of price level which remained same
Current perception of price level which has decreased

6674.name: Perceptions and Expectations on Spending- Non-Essential items
6674.overview: The bi-monthly survey studies perceptions and expectations of respondents on general economic situation, employment scenario, overall price situation and their own income and spending levels. Meanwhile, with higher expenditure on essential items, households perceived a rise in overall expenditure. Sentiments on non-essential expenditure however, continue to be pessimistic and did not reflect improvement over the coming year. In terms of economic situation, the current perception showed improvement but continued to be in negative terrain.

6675.name: Perceptions and Expectations on Spending-Essential Items
6675.overview: It should be noted that the common man needs the essential items for survival and non-essential items can be broadly classified as items for convenience. Only 2-3percent of the respondents perceived that there is a reduction in spending on essential items compared to 12-24percent, who thought that the spending has reduced on non-essential items. Hence, low-income consumers still feel the burden of price on essential items. In terms of future expectations, the picture remains the same. Increase in prices, no considerable increase in income, no reduction in the spending on essential items, and worsening of the general economic situation in the country, is what people in India are encountering.

6676.name: Product-wise Expectations of Prices for Three Months ahead
6676.overview: Reserve Bank of India has been conducting Inflation Expectations Survey of Households (IESH) on a periodic basis. The survey elicits qualitative and quantitative responses for three-month ahead and one-year ahead period on expected price changes and inflation. Inflation expectations of households (HHs) are subjective assessments and are based on their individual consumption baskets and therefore, may be different from the official inflation numbers released periodically by the government. Again, they are rather not assumed to be based on forecasts of any official measure of inflation, though these inflation expectations provide useful inputs on directional movements of future inflation.
columns: Expectation of price trend for each product in three months ahead
key_columns: Expectation of price trend for each product in three months ahead

6677.name: Product-wise Expectations of Prices for One Year ahead
6677.overview: RBI aims at capturing subjective assessments on price movements and inflation, based on their individual consumption baskets, across 19 cities. The survey seeks qualitative responses from households on price changes like general prices as well as prices of specific product groups in the three months ahead as well as in the one year ahead period and quantitative responses on current, three months ahead and one year ahead inflation rates. Even as the central bank expects inflation to be within the central bank's upper tolerance band at 6 percent by early next financial year, households still expect it to continue to remain at double digit level over a one-year time horizon, the central bank's household expectation survey found.
columns: Products on expectation trend like general, food, non food, housing etc
Expectation of price trend for each product in one year ahead.

key_columns: Products on expectation trend like general, food, non food, housing etc

6678.name: Outstanding Central Government Public Debt
6678.overview: A country's gross government debt, also called public debt or sovereign debt, is the financial liability of the government sector. Changes in government debt over time reflect primarily borrowing due to past government deficits. A deficit occurs when a government's expenditures exceed revenues. Government debt may be owed to domestic residents, as well as to foreign residents. If owed to foreign residents, that quantity is included in the country's external debt. Government debt is typically measured as the gross debt of the general government sector that is in the form of liabilities that are debt instruments. A debt instrument is a financial claim that requires payment of interest or principal by the debtor to the creditor in the future. Examples include debt securities such as bonds and bills, loans, and government employee pension obligations.
columns: Market loans securities to 364 day treasury bills

6679.name: Perceptions and Expectations on the General Economic Situation
6679.overview: Central banks’ primary objective nowadays is achieving and maintaining price stability, monitoring inflation perceptions and expectations of economic agents, and understanding their nature is extremely important for them. In particular, differences between subjectively perceived price levels, expected price levels, and official inflation could impact consumer spending and saving behavior, and thus affect overall macroeconomic outcomes. Inflation perceptions and expectations thus represent one useful indicator to predict future inflation. Economists define inflation as a sustained increase in the price level of goods and services in an economy over some time. The change in consumer confidence has the potential to affect real economic activities through changes in business sentiments. Thus, the current and expected confidence in economic and personal financial situations is of particular relevance for policy purposes.
columns: One year ahead expectation will improve
One year ahead expectation will remain same

6680.name: Real Gross Domestic Product (GDP) growth.
6680.overview: The real economic growth rate, or real GDP growth rate, measures economic growth, as expressed by gross domestic product (GDP), from one period to another, adjusted for inflation or deflation. The real economic growth rate is expressed as a percentage that shows the rate of change in a country's GDP, typically from one year to the next. It removes inflation in its measurement of economic growth, unlike the nominal GDP growth rate, and can be calculated by adjusting nominal GDP for inflation. It is also used to compare the growth rates of similar economies with different rates of inflation.

6681.name: Sector-wise Growth in Gross Value Added (GVA)
6681.overview: Gross value added (GVA) is an economic productivity metric that measures the contribution of a corporate subsidiary, company, or municipality to an economy, producer, sector, or region. GVA is the output of the country less the intermediate consumption, which is the difference between gross output and net output.
columns: Real Gross Domestic Product (GDP) Growth Rate

6682.name: Perceptions and Expectations on Employment
6682.overview: This dataset shows detailed information on perceptions and expectations of employment across all of India. Consumer confidence is an economic indicator. Based on surveys, an index is created by a conference board. The survey reveals the public perception of the country’s economic health. The survey obtains current perceptions (vis-à-vis a year ago) and one year ahead expectations on general economic situation, employment scenario, overall price situation and own income etc.

6683.name: Debt Position of the Central Government (crore)
6683.overview: This dataset covers information on the Debt Position of the Central Government in ₹ crore. The central government debt includes all liabilities of the central government contracted against the Consolidated Fund of India. The components include Public Debt, Internal Debt, External Debt, Other Liabilities, etc.

6684.name: Central Government Outstanding Debt
6684.overview: Public debt, sometimes referred to as government debt, represents the total outstanding debt, including bonds and other securities, of a country's central government. It is often expressed as a ratio of the country's Gross Domestic Product (GDP). Public debt can be raised both externally and internally. External debt is the debt owed to lenders outside the country, while internal debt represents the government's obligations to domestic lenders.

6685.name: Donor-wise Sovereign External Debt as a percentage of Total External Assistance
6685.overview: Sovereign debt issued by national governments is an unusual type of asset. In the context of the domestic financial system, it is often viewed as safer and more liquid than privately issued debt. The deep reason for this is the sovereign's power to tax future income. Buying and selling sovereign debt helps economic agents cope with liquidity shocks, smooth consumption, and realize investment opportunities. However, there is also another perspective on sovereign debt, which focuses on the difficulty of enforcing sovereign debt contracts, particularly if the holders of debt are foreign investors. The problem is not necessarily the lack of a legal framework, as sovereign debtors can issue debt in foreign jurisdictions whose legal systems are independent from the debtor's influence.

6686.name: Donor-wise Sovereign External Debt
6686.overview: Multilateral debt is the money India owes to international financial institutions such as the Asian Development Bank (ADB), the International Development Association (IDA), the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development (IBRD), the International Fund for Agricultural Development (IFAD) and others. Bilateral debt is the money India owes to foreign governments. India's external debt is held in multiple currencies, the largest of which is the United States dollar. The external debt of India is the total debt the country owes to foreign creditors. The debtors can be the Union government, state governments, corporations, or citizens of India. The debt includes money owed to private commercial banks, foreign governments, or international financial institutions such as the International Monetary Fund (IMF) and World Bank.
