6687.name: Statement Showing Weighted Average Rate of Interest (Maturity year wise) on Market Loans including Floating Rate Bonds (FRB), Converted Special Securities and Special Securities
6687.overview: Weighted Average Rate of Interest of Maturity in year wise and Market Loans including Floating Rate Bonds, Converted Special Securities, and Special Securities. The weighted average yield is largely a function of the interest rate environment. The details of maturity and yield on Central Government’s dated securities in terms of issuances during the year and Market Loans including Floating Rate Bonds (FRB), Converted Special Securities, and Special Securities.

6688.name: Outstanding Central Government Debt - Other Liabilities
6688.overview: Governments issue debt whenever they borrow from the public; the magnitude of the outstanding debt equals the cumulative amount of net borrowing that the government has done. The deficit is the addition in the current period (year, quarter, month, etc.) to the outstanding debt. The deficit is positive whenever the value of outstanding debt increases; a negative deficit is called a surplus. When the government borrows, it gives its creditors government securities stating the terms of the loan: the principal being borrowed, the interest rate to be paid on the principal, and the schedule for making the interest payments and principal repayment. The amount of outstanding securities equals the amount of debt that has not yet been repaid; that amount is called the government debt.
columns: Small savings or national small savings fund
Central government debt of state provident fund
Special securities issued to oil marketing companies, fertiliser companies and food corporation of India under other accounts
Special deposits of non-government provident fund etc. under other accounts
Outstanding central government debt in other items under other accounts
Total liabilities of external debt at current exchange rate

6689.name: Debt Position of the Central Government (As a percent of GDP)
6689.overview: General government debt-to-Gross Domestic Product(GDP) ratio measures the gross debt of the general government as a percentage of Gross Domestic Product(GDP). It is a key indicator for the sustainability of government finance. Debt is calculated as the sum of the following liability categories (as applicable): currency and deposits; debt securities, loans; insurance, pensions and standardised guarantee schemes, and other accounts payable. Changes in government debt over time primarily reflect the impact of past government deficits.
columns: Public internal debt of marketable securities plus non-marketable securities
Securities, treasury bills and cash management bills of marketable securities of internal debt in public debt
Dated securities with marketable securities of internal debt in public debt
Treasury bills of marketable securities in internal debt under public debt
Cash management bills of marketable securities in internal debt under public debt
Non-marketable securities of internal public debt
14-day intermediate Treasury-Bill (T-Bill) of non-marketable securities with internal public debt
Compensation & other bonds of non-marketable securities with internal public debt
Securities issued to International Financial (intl. Fin.) Institutions of non-marketable securities in internal public debt
Securities against small savings of non-marketable securities of internal public debt
Special securities against post office life insurance fund in non-marketable securities of internal public debt

Special securities issued to Public Sector Banks (PSB), Export-Import Bank of the United States (EXIM) bank, Industrial Development Bank of India Limited (IDBI) bank and India Infrastructure Finance Company Ltd (IIFCL) of non-marketable securities in internal public debt (%)
National Small Savings Fund to NSSF loans fully serviced by Government of India (GoI) of other liabilities in public account
National Small Savings Fund of other liabilities in public account
State provident funds of other liabilities in public account

Total liabilities and the sum of public debt, public account-other liabilities and extra-budgetary resources

6690.name: List of Government Securities issued to National Social Security Fund (NSSF) Outstanding
6690.overview: All deposits under small savings schemes are credited to the National Small Savings Fund (NSSF), established in the public account of India. All withdrawals by the depositors are made out of the accumulations in this fund. The balance in the fund is invested in special government securities as per norms decided from time to time by the central government. Interest as discussed by the government from time to time is payable on the special securities issued by state or Union Territories (UT) Governments against their share of net collections.

6691.name: Outstanding Central Government Securities
6691.overview: Government securities are investment products issued by the both central and state government of India in the form of bonds, treasury bills, or notes. They are generally issued for the purpose of refunding maturity securities for advance refunding of securities that have not yet matured and raising fresh cash resources. However, they carry minimal risk and are called risk-free gilt-edged instruments.

6692.name: Currency Composition of Sovereign External Debt
6692.overview: Public debt, or sovereign debt, is an important way for governments to finance investments in growth and development. However, it is also critical that governments are able to continue servicing their debt and that their debt burden remains sustainable. Entering into debt distress is often a painful process, which may threaten macro-economic stability and set back a country’s development for years. Supporting member countries in managing debt risks and resolving debt distress is therefore at the heart of the International Monetary Fund(IMF) work. This work takes multiple forms.
columns: Currency composition of sovereign external debt Rs in Crore

6693.name: Perceptions and Expectations on Income (Percentage Responses)
6693.overview: The survey obtains current perceptions and one-year-ahead expectations on the general economic situation, employment scenario, overall price situation, and respondents own income and spending across 19 major cities. Households expressed pessimism about their current income, but a majority of them expect higher income over the next year. CSI and FEI are compiled on the basis of net responses on the economic situation, income, spending, employment, and price level for the current period (as compared with one year ago) and a year ahead, respectively.
columns: Current perception of income which has increased
Current perception of income which has remained same
Current perception of income which has decreased
Current perception of income net response
Expectation on income which will improve over one year ahead
Expectation on income which will remain same over one year ahead
Expectation on income which will decrease over one year ahead
Net Response on one year ahead expectation on income

6694.name: Ownership Pattern of Government of India Dated Securities (Face Value)
6694.overview: Government securities are primarily held by domestic institutional investors. The ownership pattern of dated securities indicates that commercial banks continued to be the largest holder of total outstanding G-Secs with a share of 40.4 percent. The ownership pattern indicates a broad-based investor base, with commercial banks and insurance companies being the predominant investor categories. Notwithstanding a decline in the share of commercial banks in outstanding stock of central government-dated securities over the years, they have remained the largest investor class.

6695.name: Category-wise Buying and Selling under Outright Transactions in Secondary Market
6695.overview: This dataset provides detailed information on category-wise buying and selling under outright transactions in the secondary market. Outright transactions are purchases or sales of securities without any agreement to buy or sell back on a specific day. Transactions with such buying-back or selling-back conditions are called transactions with repurchase agreements.

6696.name: Pradhan Mantri Jan Dhan Yojana District wise House Hold Report
6696.overview: Pradhan Mantri Jan-Dhan Yojana (PMJDY) is a National Mission on Financial Inclusion encompassing an integrated approach to bring about comprehensive financial inclusion of all the households in the country. The plan envisages universal access to banking facilities with at least one basic banking account for every household, financial literacy, access to credit, insurance and pension facility. In addition, the beneficiaries would get RuPay Debit card having inbuilt accident insurance cover of र 1 lakh. The plan also envisages channelling all Government benefits (from Centre / State / Local Body) to the beneficiaries accounts and pushing the Direct Benefits Transfer (DBT) scheme of the Union Government.
columns: Number of wards allotted in Sub Service Areas (SSAs)
Number of wards surveyed in Sub Service Areas (SSAs)

6697.name: Instrument-Wise Breakup of Outright Trades
6697.overview: An outright futures position is a long or short trade that is not hedged from market risk. Both the potential gain and the potential risk are greater for outright positions than for positions that are covered or hedged in some way. An outright position is one that stands on its own and is not part of a larger or more complex trade. A profit is made from a long outright futures position if the price rises following the purchase, or from a short trade if the price falls after the short is initiated.
columns: Volumes of instrument-wise breakup of outright trades
Average volumes of instrument-wise breakup of outright trades
Share of instrument-wise breakup of outright trades

6698.name: Financing of Gross Fiscal Deficit of the Central Government
6698.overview: The Gross Fiscal Deficit (GFD) represents the amount by which total expenditure, including loans net of recovery, exceeds revenue receipts, which include external grants and non-debt capital receipts. The net fiscal deficit, on the other hand, is calculated by subtracting net lending of the central government from the Gross Fiscal Deficit. The fiscal deficit, which is the difference between the total revenue and total expenditure of the government, indicates the total borrowings required by the government. When calculating the total revenue, borrowings are not taken into account.
columns: Internal financing of National Social Security Fund (NSSF) or small savings
Internal financing of state provident funds
Internal financing of drawdown of cash balances
Internal financing with financing from other sources

6699.name: Turnover Ratio
6699.overview: Ensuring improved liquidity in the secondary market for Government Securities (G-Secs) is crucial to minimize the interest rate risk resulting from the illiquidity premium for dated securities. This can be achieved through higher turnover and an increase in the number of market participants. This dataset provides information on the percentage of turnover ratios across various categories.
columns: Turnover ratio of state development loans (sdls) ( % )

6700.name: Land holdings of Central Public Sector Enterprises (CPSEs)
6700.overview: Out of the total of 389 CPSEs, 239 CPSEs have furnished the details of land holdings for PE Survey. The data furnished by CPSEs are approximate/provisional measure and actual records of individual parcels of land are available with the respective CPSEs
columns: Number of Central Public Sector Enterprises (CPSEs) reported land data

6702.name: Issuance of 364-day, 182-day, 91-day Treasury Bills
6702.overview: Government Treasury bill is issued as a short-term fundraising tool for the government and has the highest maturity period of 364 days. Individuals looking to generate short term gains through secure investments can choose to park their funds in such securities. Reserve Bank of India’s (RBI) Treasury bill yields have surpassed the returns of most bank fixed deposit schemes. The cut-off yield of Reserve Bank of India’s (RBI) Treasury bills (T-bills) maturing in 364 days or yield-to-maturity currently stands at 6.87 per cent, which most fixed deposit schemes do not give in a year.

6703.name: Secondary Market Transactions in Government Securities
6703.overview: Government Securities (G-Secs) are securities issued by the central government or the state government. These securities represent the market borrowings of the centre and respective States. They are issued for financing the fiscal deficit and managing the temporary cash mismatches of the government. Broadly, Government Securities (G-Secs) can be classified as Dated Government Securities (G-secs) , State Development Loans (SDL) and Treasury Bills. Dated Government Securities (G-Secs) are those securities which are issued by the central government and are the most actively traded out of the three instruments. State Development Loans (SDL), refer to borrowings of the state governments. Treasury Bills are shorter tenor securities, ranging from 91 Days to 364 Days, issued for the purpose of meeting short term liquidity mismatches of the Central Government.
columns: Government securities namely government securities, treasury bills and state development loans
Secondary market transactions in government securities
key_columns: Government securities namely government securities, treasury bills and state development loans

6704.name: Secondary Market Outright Transactions-Central Government Dated Securities
6704.overview: This dataset provides detailed information on Secondary Market Outright Transactions on Central Government Dated Securities. Outright transactions mean purchases/sales of securities without any agreement to buy/sell back on a specific day. Transactions with such buying/selling back conditions are called transactions with repurchase agreements.
columns: Type of Residual Maturity in years
key_columns: Type of Residual Maturity in years

6705.name: State-wise Distribution of Select Items of Scheduled Commercial Banks Advances to Priority Sector
6705.overview: This dataset provides detail information on State wise Distribution of Select Items of Scheduled Commercial Banks Advances to Priority Sector. Scheduled Commercial Banks are the banks that were encompassed in the second schedule of the RBI Act 1934. The major services that scheduled commercial bank offers are accepting deposits, granting different loans, credit and debit cards, and other such financial services.
columns: Number of accounts in Scheduled Commercial Banks advances to Priority Sector
6705.collection: RBI- Data Base on Indian Economy (DBIE)

6710.name: Pensioner's Count
6710.overview: Dataset providing information on beneficiaries with pension account and payment of their pensions through various modes of payment namely bank, post office, money order and cash.
columns: Pension payment through money order payment system
